text: You get a text claiming to be from your delivery service with a short link to reschedule. What should you do first?

options.text: Tap the link and log in quickly.
Ignore the text and delete it immediately.
Open the delivery app directly to check your order status.
Reply STOP to the number.

why: Smishing often uses shortened links. Opening the official app or website avoids malicious links.
action: Open the trusted app or type the official URL in your browser; do not click the texted link.

text: An email warns your mailbox is full and asks you to 're-validate' using a button. The sender domain is 'support-mailbox.co'. Best first move?

options.text: Click the button and re-enter your credentials.
Hover over the button to preview the URL and verify the domain.
Forward it to your team so they can be aware.
Reply asking if it's legitimate.

why: Look-alike domains are a common phishing tactic. Hovering shows the true destination.
action: Hover to inspect the link; if suspicious, report and visit your account via the official site instead.

text: A QR code flyer in the office lobby promises 'mandatory benefits update—scan to sign'. What is safest?

options.text: Scan it and sign in with work credentials.
Take a photo and scan later at home.
Confirm with HR via the official portal or email before scanning.
Peel the flyer off and throw it away.

why: Quishing (QR phishing) can send you to fake login pages.
action: Verify the request via official HR channels; access updates from the known HR portal, not ad‑hoc QR codes.

text: You receive a voicemail that sounds like your manager urgently asking for gift cards. The number is unfamiliar. Best action?

options.text: Comply quickly to avoid delay.
Call back the number that left the voicemail.
Independently contact your manager using a known channel to verify.
Text the caller for more details.

why: Deepfake or spoofed voice scams use urgency and alternate numbers.
action: Validate using a trusted contact method (directory/Teams) before acting on unusual requests.

text: Your browser shows an OAuth consent screen for a new 'AI‑Doc Helper' requesting access to read your company drive. Colleague shared a doc link that triggered it. What now?

options.text: Approve access; it helps with documents.
Deny and verify the app is approved in your organization's app catalog.
Approve if the colleague says it's safe in chat.
Ignore; closing the tab is enough.

why: Malicious apps can exfiltrate data via OAuth without passwords.
action: Deny, then check your organization's approved apps list or contact IT before granting scopes.

text: You get multiple MFA push requests you did not initiate (MFA fatigue). Best immediate response?

options.text: Approve one to stop the prompts.
Deny all and change your password; notify security.
Disable MFA temporarily.
Ignore them; they will stop eventually.

why: Attackers spam approvals hoping you accept by mistake.
action: Deny, rotate credentials, and alert security to investigate suspicious sign‑ins.

text: A LinkedIn message from a recruiter sends a 'role spec' via a public drive link asking you to sign in with your work account. What should you do?

options.text: Use work credentials to access the file.
Ask for the document via your company's applicant portal or share a non‑work email.
Share your phone number for faster coordination.
Forward to colleagues to check.

why: Social‑engineering often moves targets to credential‑harvesting sites.
action: Use trusted recruiting channels; avoid entering work creds into unknown public links.

text: Your inbox shows a 'thread‑hijack' reply in an existing vendor chain with a new invoice link. The sender's display name matches but the domain changed subtly. What next?

options.text: Pay immediately to keep terms.
Open the link in a sandbox browser.
Validate via a known vendor contact and compare the domain against previous messages.
Reply asking for bank details to verify.

why: Business email compromise often uses conversation hijacking with look‑alike domains.
action: Out‑of‑band verify with the vendor; check domain history in prior emails before acting.

text: Security alerts you that your account created a new mail‑forwarding rule to an external address. You did not create it. First best step?

options.text: Delete the rule and move on.
Reset password, revoke active sessions/tokens, enable device check, and report the incident.
Email the external address asking why.
Disable your mailbox temporarily.

why: Forwarding rules indicate possible mailbox compromise.
action: Rotate creds, invalidate sessions/app passwords, review rules, and notify security per incident process.

text: You suspect a vendor portal login page is fake but it uses HTTPS and a valid certificate. How do you verify safely?

options.text: Certificate means it's safe—log in.
Check the URL carefully for typos and navigate via a known bookmark or typed domain.
Open it in incognito; if it loads, it's legit.
Ask the sender for a screenshot of their login.

why: HTTPS only encrypts traffic; it does not prove legitimacy of the site you intended.
action: Type the official URL or use a saved bookmark; avoid email links when uncertain.

text: A spear‑phish references a recent internal project and asks you to share a private doc externally via personal Gmail. What is the safest response?

options.text: Share but remove edit rights.
Decline and report; verify with the project owner via a known internal channel.
Create a copy on your desktop and send it.
Ask the sender to send from their personal email too for confirmation.

why: Attackers use internal details from previous leaks or recon.
action: Use internal channels and DLP policies; never share sensitive docs to personal emails without approval.

text: A 'security update' page requests your recovery codes after you enabled a new authenticator. It claims 'codes required to sync'. What do you do?

options.text: Enter the codes so your devices stay in sync.
Provide one code only; keep others safe.
Stop and report; recovery codes should never be asked by web forms.
Disable MFA to avoid the prompt.

why: Recovery codes are sensitive; legitimate sites won't ask you to submit them to 'verify'.
action: Report the page and rotate MFA secrets if you suspect exposure.

text: Your browser suggests using a generated password when creating an account. What should you do?

options.text: Use the strong generated password and save it.
Use your favorite password to remember easily.
Use 'CompanyName2024' for consistency.
Skip saving; email it to yourself.

why: Unique, long passwords reduce credential‑stuffing risk.
action: Use a password manager or built‑in generator and save the credential.

text: Which is the best example of a strong password practice?

options.text: Reusing a complex password across sites.
Using a passphrase like 'taco-river-lamp-galaxy' unique to the site.
Using your pet's name with numbers.
Short password plus frequent changes.

why: Unique passphrases are strong and memorable.
action: Create unique passphrases per site; avoid reuse.

text: You receive a credential‑exposed alert for a streaming site you rarely use. What should you do regarding your work accounts?

options.text: Nothing—it's not work related.
Change only the streaming site password.
If you reused that password anywhere (including work), change those and enable MFA.
Close the streaming account and ignore.

why: Password reuse turns minor breaches into major risk.
action: Rotate any reused credentials and turn on MFA.

text: Your teammate asks for your password to 'check something quickly'. What's correct?

options.text: Share temporarily and change it later.
Decline; accounts are individual and auditable.
Share over chat so there's a record.
Write it on a sticky note for them.

why: Account sharing breaks accountability and policy.
action: Use proper access requests or pair while the owner is logged in.

text: Your organization is rolling out passkeys. Which is the safest approach?

options.text: Disable MFA because passkeys replace it.
Enroll passkeys on at least two authenticators and keep recovery options updated.
Use one device only so it's simple.
Share passkeys with your assistant for backups.

why: Redundancy prevents lockout; passkeys resist phishing but still need backups.
action: Register multiple authenticators (phone + security key) and store recovery codes securely.

text: Your password manager prompts that your work password appears in a known breach. Next best step?

options.text: Dismiss; it's probably old.
Change the password immediately and review reuse across sites.
Turn off notifications; they're distracting.
Email the password to IT for review.

why: Exposure alerts require immediate rotation and reuse checks.
action: Change the password, enable MFA, and ensure uniqueness across services.

text: You find a shared team account without MFA protecting a production dashboard. Policy allows 'break‑glass' accounts only. What should you do?

options.text: Use it temporarily; add MFA later.
Report and migrate to individual accounts with least privilege and MFA.
Change the shared password and DM the team.
Write it in a secure spreadsheet.

why: Shared accounts remove accountability and are risky without MFA.
action: Replace with individual accounts + MFA; reserve break‑glass with strict controls.

text: A contractor requests temporary elevated access for a maintenance window. What's the most secure way to grant it?

options.text: Give admin and ask them to be careful.
Grant just‑in‑time, least‑privilege access with time‑bound approval and auditing.
Share a permanent admin account then rotate later.
Ask them to use your account for convenience.

why: JIT access reduces exposure and is auditable.
action: Use privileged access management to provide time‑boxed rights with logs.

text: You suspect an employee's password was phished but MFA stopped the login. What's the correct incident response?

options.text: Do nothing since MFA blocked it.
Force password reset, revoke sessions/tokens, review sign‑in logs, and check for mail rules.
Tell the user to be careful next time.
Disable the account for a week.

why: Credentials may still be exposed; sessions and tokens can persist.
action: Rotate, revoke, and investigate indicators of compromise per IR playbook.

text: You need to store app secrets used by a CI pipeline. Best practice?

options.text: Commit them encrypted to the repo.
Use a secrets manager with scoped access and rotation.
Email them to the build server admin.
Keep them in an environment variable forever.

why: Centralized secrets managers provide rotation, auditing, and least privilege.
action: Use a secrets vault (e.g., cloud KMS/secret manager) with rotation policy and minimal scope.

text: Your SOC flags successful logins from two distant countries within 30 minutes for the same user. What control helps most here?

options.text: Password rotation every 30 days.
Impossible travel detection with conditional access step‑up.
Disabling copy‑paste in password fields.
Forcing complex special characters.

why: Behavioral analytics can block or step‑up auth for anomalous patterns.
action: Enable conditional access to challenge or block on impossible travel events.

text: An executive insists on storing passwords in a personal spreadsheet. What's the best remediation approach?

options.text: Allow it if the file is encrypted.
Move credentials to an enterprise password manager with role‑based sharing and audit logs.
Ask their assistant to manage the sheet.
Print the passwords and lock them.

why: Enterprise managers provide controlled sharing, auditing, and security features.
action: Migrate to a managed vault; disable personal storage of credentials for work.

text: At an airport, two Wi‑Fi networks have the airport name. Which do you join?

options.text: The one with the strongest signal.
Any—public Wi‑Fi is safe with HTTPS.
Confirm the official SSID with staff/signage and use that.
Create a hotspot named after the airport and use it.

why: Evil‑twin networks mimic names to intercept traffic.
action: Verify the official SSID and use a VPN for work.

text: You're asked to plug a 'charging station USB' into your laptop at a conference. What should you do?

options.text: Plug it in; it's just power.
Use a USB data‑blocker or your own charger; avoid unknown USB devices.
Borrow a cable from someone else.
Disable Wi‑Fi first then plug it in.

why: Juice‑jacking and HID attacks can use USB data pins.
action: Use your own wall charger or a data‑blocking adapter.

text: While on hotel Wi‑Fi, your laptop prompts to 'share files with devices on this network'. What's correct?

options.text: Enable it for faster sharing.
Enable only if you trust all guests.
Keep device discovery/file sharing OFF on public networks.
Turn it on and off as needed each time.

why: Public networks increase lateral exposure.
action: Use 'Public network' profile; keep sharing/discovery off.

text: Your phone offers to auto‑join known public networks. What is safest?

options.text: Allow auto‑join for convenience.
Disable auto‑join for public SSIDs and forget old networks.
Rename networks to avoid confusion.
Use airplane mode instead of Wi‑Fi.

why: Auto‑join can connect you to spoofed SSIDs without notice.
action: Turn off auto‑join on public networks; prune old SSIDs.

text: You're traveling and must access internal dashboards. What's the most secure setup?

options.text: Public Wi‑Fi + saved password in browser.
Public Wi‑Fi + corporate VPN + device compliance (disk encryption, screen lock).
Phone hotspot without VPN.
Hotel ethernet without updates.

why: VPN with compliant device posture reduces exposure on untrusted networks.
action: Connect via corporate VPN on a compliant, updated device.

text: A coworker AirDrops you a 'conference agenda.pdf' in a crowded hall. Your device name is visible. Best practice?

options.text: Accept to save time.
Set AirDrop/Nearby Share to 'Contacts only' or 'Receiving off'.
Rename device to something generic only.
Turn on Bluetooth discoverable mode.

why: Public sharing exposes you to unsolicited files and tracking.
action: Restrict device‑to‑device sharing in public spaces.

text: You must print a boarding pass at a cybercafé. Which is safest?

options.text: Log into your work email on the public PC and print.
Use your phone to access the airline then AirPrint/WebPrint directly; avoid logging into work on public PCs.
Email the PDF to the shop clerk.
Insert your USB drive into the public PC to print.

why: Public PCs may have keyloggers/malware; avoid work logins and removable media use.
action: Use your own device to retrieve and print; avoid entering credentials on public PCs.

text: Your laptop firewall asks about allowing inbound connections for a new conference app on hotel Wi‑Fi. Best choice?

options.text: Allow on all networks.
Allow on private networks only; block on public networks.
Block everywhere; uninstall the app.
Allow if the signal is strong.

why: Restrict inbound services on public networks to reduce attack surface.
action: Permit only on trusted/private networks; block on public.

text: While using café Wi‑Fi, a captive portal asks you to install a 'security certificate' to continue. What should you do?

options.text: Install it; portals require certificates.
Decline; installing unknown root certificates can enable HTTPS interception.
Install then remove after browsing.
Switch to cellular; certificates are harmless.

why: Malicious or misconfigured root certs can intercept encrypted traffic.
action: Do not install untrusted certificates; use VPN or cellular instead.

text: You must join a client guest Wi‑Fi requiring MAC address registration. What is the most secure device posture beforehand?

options.text: Disable OS updates to avoid reboots.
Ensure full‑disk encryption, OS patches, EDR, and screen lock are enabled.
Turn off the firewall to reduce prompts.
Create a new local admin for the trip.

why: Hardened, updated devices limit impact on untrusted networks.
action: Travel with a compliant, encrypted, EDR‑protected device.

text: A kiosk prints your boarding pass but also displays your email briefly. What additional risk exists and what to do?

options.text: No risk; kiosks are isolated.
Residual data and keylogging risk; avoid entering work creds and clear caches/close sessions.
Only risk is shoulder surfing; stand closer.
Use incognito to eliminate risk entirely.

why: Shared machines can store data or run malware.
action: Avoid work logins; if used, sign out, clear data, and change passwords if necessary.

text: During travel, you lose your corporate laptop. What's the first best step to reduce exposure?

options.text: Change your email password later.
Report immediately so IT can remote‑wipe/disable and start incident response.
Buy a replacement and restore from personal backup.
Post in chat asking if anyone saw it.

why: Rapid response (remote wipe/disable) limits data exposure and supports legal/regulatory steps.
action: Report loss immediately; IT can revoke tokens and wipe the device per policy.
